        Consolidated Content:
The Mayflower was an English ship that transported the first English Puritans, known today as the Pilgrims, from Plymouth, England, to the New World in 1620. The ship had 102 passengers, and the crew is estimated to have been about 30. The captain of the Mayflower was Christopher Jones, who was about 50 years old and from Harwich, a seaport in Essex, England. He and his ship were veterans of the European cargo business, often carrying wine to England, but neither had ever crossed the Atlantic. By June 1620, he and the Mayflower had been hired for the Pilgrims' voyage by their business agents in London, Thomas Weston of the Merchant Adventurers and Robert Cushman.
